thread.title: Innu Nation deputy Simeon Tshakapesh convicted of impaired driving
thread.title_full: Innu Nation deputy Simeon Tshakapesh convicted of impaired driving

author: cbc
title: Innu Nation deputy Simeon Tshakapesh convicted of impaired driving
text:
The Deputy Grand Chief of the Innu Nation has been convicted of two counts of impaired driving in Happy Valley-Goose Bay.
Simeon Tshakapesh, of Natuashish, was originally scheduled for a brief court appearance by phone, but when the judge asked if he'd had chance to speak to a lawyer, Tshakapesh said he hadn't and that he wanted to plead guilty.
After a quick recess and a phone conversation with duty counsel, Tshakapesh officially entered his plea Tuesday.
He later apologized and said driving drunk was the "stupidest thing" he'd ever done.
Tshakapesh was elected deputy grand chief of the Innu Nation in 2014. Prior to that, he served as band council chief in Natuashish, where he lobbied unsuccessfully to repeal an alcohol ban, which still exists in that community.
More than twice the limit According to an agreed statement of facts, someone called police after seeing Tshakapesh leave a liquor store in Happy Valley-Goose Bay on Dec. 30, 2016 around 11 a.m. The RCMP waited for him along Route 520, between Happy Valley-Goose Bay and Sheshatshiu.
Police stopped Tshakapesh and gave him a breathalyzer, which showed a blood alcohol level of 190 mg — more than twice the legal limit of 80 mg.
As for punishment, the Crown and the defence both asked for a fine and driving ban.
Tshakapesh has two prior convictions: being unlawfully intoxicated while on reserve and breaching probation.
Judge Phyllis Harris considered Tshakapesh's record, his prompt guilty plea, and the severity of his crime — Tshakapesh travelled nearly 20 kilometres before being stopped with four passengers in his truck.
The judge settled on a $1,500 fine and a 12-month driving ban.
